Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They check a routine prescription for a common cold and confirm the medication matches the label.
Story:
I glance at the clock on the pharmacy wall—6:55 p.m. My shift ends in five minutes, but the line at the counter hasn’t shrunk. My phone vibrates in my pocket, and I know it’s my mom. Every Thursday at 7 p.m., I call home. It’s our ritual, a promise I made when I moved out. My parents wait for my call, eager for stories about my week, and I know how much it means to them. 

But right now, a customer hands me a prescription for a common cold. I scan the label, double-check the medication, and my mind races. I can’t rush this—one mistake could harm someone. Yet, my phone keeps buzzing, and guilt gnaws at me. I picture my parents sitting by the phone, waiting, maybe worrying if I’m okay. I want to be a good child, to reassure them, but I also have a duty here, to be precise and careful. My heart pounds as I weigh the expectations pressing in from both sides, feeling torn between the people who raised me and the patients who trust me.
